data.title: Test: more keybinding labels in menus and context menus
data.body:
- [x] win @alexandrudima 
- [x] os x @chrmarti 
- [x] linux @isidorn 

Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14622

We are using the Electron menu API to show keybindings. Unfortunately not every keybinding can be displayed natively through this API. We now have a fallback for those keybindings that we cannot show to show them as part of the menu label.
* verify you see all keybindings in menus and context menus even if the keybinding is a chord
* verify the menu still updates live from changes you do to keybindings

data.title: Markdown: editor jumps up while typing having preview open
data.body:
Noticed this since a couple of days that when I type in the editor with markdown, sometimes the editor would jump up, even though I am not giving focus to the markdown preview that is opened on the right hand side.

This happens to me editing our release notes. I am on macOS and have a zoom level of 1.

![kapture 2017-02-10 at 17 43 00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/22835278/6b34eb02-efb8-11e6-9929-355f6875056c.gif)

I think I would never change the scrolling on the editor unless I am scrolling inside the markdown preview.

data.title: Typing in Find adds many non relevant entries to navigation history

data.body:
When typing in the Find in file input box, many entries are added to navigation history.
After doing a search, I often want to return to the previous location I was at prior to launching find; however, that is often not possible as navigation history is full of locations that were jumped to during typing in the find input box.

data.title: Test: debug tree keyboard actions
data.body:
- [x] win @bpasero 
- [x] mac @joaomoreno 
- [x] linux @jrieken 

Refs: #20419
Complexity: 2

We have restructured how we handle keyboard actions in trees. This test plan item is about trees used in the debug land. Have a workspace that you can debug (example: smoke test app), start debugging and verify:
* You can use `up / down` keys to navigate between varios trees in the debug pane
* You can use `space` to enable / disable brekapoints
* You can use `delete` (mac: `cmd + bakcspace`) to delete breakpoints or watch expressions
* You can use `enter` to navigate to a breakpoint location
* You can use F2 (mac: 'enter') to rename watch expresisons and set variable values

Feedback on adding new keybinding which are intuitive is welcome.

data.title: Test: configurable window title
data.body:
- [x] win @egamma 
- [x] os x @kieferrm 
- [x] linux @mousetraps 

Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1723

We added a new setting `window.title `that can be used to alter the window title when opening files.
* verify you can change this setting and the change applies live and is preserved between restarts
* verify the description and behaviour of the setting and the variables makes sense to you and work
* if you have ideas for additional variables, feel free to report back

data.title: Disconnect icon doesn't appear when PowerShell debugger attaches to process
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 AU (1607)
- PowerShell extension version: 0.9.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode
2. Open command palette and type "PowerShell: Open Examples" and press Enter
3. Open file DebugTest.ps1
4. Open a PowerShell console
5. Execute $pid in the Powershell terminal to see process id
6. In Debug view, select the Attach to config and press F5.
7. Select the pid for the terminal and press Enter

Once the debugger is connected, notice the debug actions pane shows the stop button instead of the disconnect button.

Related - https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/issues/486

cc @isidorn

data.title: CodeActionProvider triggered on moving the cursor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

I noticed a performance slowdown with my language server recently. I found out it's under a kind of a *denial of service* attack coming from the latest version of VSCode. It's asking for code actions every time the cursor is placed inside a word. When I scroll through a file using the arrow keys the lanuguage server is being asked many times to provide code actions. 

The following GIF shows the requests sent by VSCode while moving the cursor:

![codeactionfoo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3448684/22832517/9dcd266a-efae-11e6-9ce0-8c4f8eb4d46e.gif)

I was wondering if this behaviour is intended. So I looked up the [language server protocol documentation](https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/blob/master/protocol.md). It says:

> The code action request is sent from the client to the server to compute commands for a given text document and range. The request is triggered when the user moves the cursor into **a problem marker** in the editor or presses the lightbulb associated with a marker.

As you can see the requests are sent without moving the cursor into a problem marker.
Is the documentation outdated? If yes is there a way to get the currently documented behaviour back?

data.title: Alt+O doesn't honor files.exclude
data.body:
When swithching to matching header file, which is in another folder, all goes well. But switching back picks another matching source file (same folder as header file). Despite excluding all .c files in that folder. 

E.g having src/file.c open and hitting Alt+O.
```
src/file.c
obj/file.c (should be exluded by files.exclude rule)
obj/file.h
```

Rule: `"**/obj/*.c": true`

data.title: Find in Files (or Replace in Files) with selection should start immediately and not take the focus
data.body:
If I select some text and then do Ctrl+Shift+F (or H) it should start the search immediately. Currently I have to press Enter to start it.

I appreciate that it is only a single key press, but it's seems inconsistent with the normal find function (Ctrl+F) which works immediately, and it sort of breaks my 'flow' as I use two hands to press Ctrl+Shift+F, which means I have to move my right hand back to the Enter key.

With normal Find, I can press Escape to refocus the main window - this doesn't work with Find in Files either, so I have to then use the mouse to refocus the main window.

As the results are displayed in a separate window, it shouldn't even really require focusing the search box if some text was already selected.

data.title: Problems: Convert hardcoded tree actions to configurable commands
data.body:
When you take a look at the controller in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/markers/browser/markersTreeController.ts#L27 there are a bunch of hardcoded keybindings associated for certain actions. We should avoid this and rather introduce commands that the user can associate keybindings with.

As part of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11517 I introduced a new service `IListService` that every tree is registering to. This service tracks focus of the tree and enables a `listFocus` context key whenever the tree has focus. As part of the `register` method you can pass over additional context keys that you want to have set for your domain (e.g. `problemsFocus`). E.g. the "Open Editors View" is doing that [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/views/openEditorsView.ts#L125). 

I suggest to write new commands that are enabled in the context for the domain (e.g. `problemsFocus`) and remove the hardcoded keybinding handling in the tree controller. When doing so I would pick short and descriptive command Ids (e.g. `problems.something` over `workbench.action.problems.something`).

If you need to overwrite a certain keybinding that already exists from the list service (e.g. <kbd>Space</kbd> should do something else than toggling), you can give your command a higher weight (see for example how the explorer is [overriding](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/fileActions.contribution.ts#L242) <kbd>Enter</kbd> to do something else on macOS).

data.title: Debug: Convert hardcoded tree actions to configurable commands
data.body:
When you take a look at the controller in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/debugViewer.ts#L187 and the related subclasses, there are a bunch of hardcoded keybindings associated for certain actions. We should avoid this and rather introduce commands that the user can associate keybindings with.

As part of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11517 I introduced a new service `IListService` that every tree is registering to. This service tracks focus of the tree and enables a `listFocus` context key whenever the tree has focus. As part of the `register` method you can pass over additional context keys that you want to have set for your domain (e.g. `breakpointsFocus`). E.g. the "Open Editors View" is doing that [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/views/openEditorsView.ts#L125). 

I suggest to write new commands that are enabled in the context for the domain (e.g. `breakpointsFocus`) and remove the hardcoded keybinding handling in the tree controller. When doing so I would pick short and descriptive command Ids (e.g. `debug.something` over `workbench.action.debug.something`).

If you need to overwrite a certain keybinding that already exists from the list service (e.g. <kbd>Space</kbd> should do something else than toggling), you can give your command a higher weight (see for example how the explorer is [overriding](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/fileActions.contribution.ts#L242) <kbd>Enter</kbd> to do something else on macOS).

data.title: Search: Convert hardcoded tree actions to configurable commands
data.body:
When you take a look at the controller in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/search/browser/searchResultsView.ts#L222 there are a bunch of hardcoded keybindings associated for certain actions. We should avoid this and rather introduce commands that the user can associate keybindings with.

As part of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11517 I introduced a new service `IListService` that every tree is registering to. This service tracks focus of the tree and enables a `listFocus` context key whenever the tree has focus. As part of the `register` method you can pass over additional context keys that you want to have set for your domain (e.g. `searchFocus`). E.g. the "Open Editors View" is doing that [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/views/openEditorsView.ts#L125). 

I suggest to write new commands that are enabled in the context for the domain (e.g. `searchFocus`) and remove the hardcoded keybinding handling in the tree controller. When doing so I would pick short and descriptive command Ids (e.g. `search.something` over `workbench.action.search.something`).

If you need to overwrite a certain keybinding that already exists from the list service (e.g. <kbd>Space</kbd> should do something else than toggling), you can give your command a higher weight (see for example how the explorer is [overriding](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/fileActions.contribution.ts#L242) <kbd>Enter</kbd> to do something else on macOS).

data.title: Allow better control over Windows font antialising

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: none

---

Normally, text rendering on Windows in VSCode uses subpixel antialiasing, where the display is assumed to be a TN LCD panel with a horizontal R-G-B subpixel arrangement.

Unfortunately, on an IPS or VA panel, this appears to produce chroma bleed and does not give the same benefit as with a TN panel (eg, the text does not appear sharper), as the subpixel structure is fundamentally different.  In my experience, for IPS and VA panels, grayscale antialiasing produces better results when rendering text.

I don't see a setting in VSCode to configure this, and while the Windows 10 Control Panel -> Display -> Cleartype setting can be changed to grayscale antialiasing, this was ignored for me in VSCode.  (Cleartype setting is GDI only?)
  
* In Sublime Text (Win10), the setting `font_options` can be set to `no_antialias`, `gray_antialias`, and `subpixel_antialias`.  
* In Chrome (Win10), the flag `chrome://flags/#lcd-text-aa` can be set to `disabled` to enable grayscale font antialiasing.  
* [This page](http://peter.sh/experiments/chromium-command-line-switches/) suggests `--disable-lcd-text` as a command-line argument in Chromium, perhaps similar to the Chrome flag.  Unfortunately, it had no effect with VSCode.  

Please consider adding a similar preference to VSCode if possible.  Thanks!

data.title: Feature Request: Support search operators in Problems tab filter field

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: MacOS & Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a codebase with a large number of **errors** and **warnings** in the source files
2. Open the Problems panel
3. Type the keyword _"error"_ in the filter input to show only **errors** and filter out **warnings**

Current behaviour:

- Any **warnings** which contain the word _"error"_ in their message also appear alongside **errors**

Desired behaviour:

- The possibility to categorically show only one type of problem. This could be done, for example, with search operators like _"type:error"_, &c.

Related issues:

- #8305
